body:
Apparently...these 12 people were assigned work as missionaries to the twelve tribes of Israel. That's about it. Otherwise, they were no different than any other believer. "Apostle" itself is a deceitful term. Most bibles refuse to translate this word to conceal the true meaning, which is, most literally, "one sent", employed to mean a messenger or missionary. *This was an everyday term in the Hellenistic world*. But you are not supposed to know about that. You are supposed to think that the 12 apostles are subordinate gods with authority of their own, and not merely representing the one true god. 

"What about how they wrote scripture?"

I hate to break it to you, but most likely the only apostle who wrote anything in your bible is Paul. Who, by the way, was himself *not* part of the 12, yet still called an apostle, and so were his partners! And what was his work? That's right, he was an evangelist, a missionary, who traveled the world to preach! The letters of the other apostles are either forgeries (some of "Paul's" are too), or a benevolent student of them writing with their name after their death or when they weren't able to, as was considered a noble practice in the ancient world. The bible canon was decided at the council of Rome in 382. We can clearly see that being part of the twelve has no connection to any kind of authority to write "scripture". Even Paul did not realize his letters would be revised and collected into "the bible" and read by millions as more authoritative than Jesus. He was merely writing letters to churches as part of his evangelizing work. Paul, Barnabas, Timothy, and the twelve were no different from what we would call a missionary today, and αποστολος was just the term they used for it back then.

"What about the parts of the bible describing their authority?"

These are later additions by the Catholic redactors. The Acts twelve and the Acts Paul who are basically portrayed as gods have discrepancies their actual descriptions in the gospels and Paul's own letters at almost every point. We are very lucky to have the gospel of Mark preserved with its negative depictions of the twelve to prove this point. Mark is the most primitive gospel and barely made the cut for the canon. And that means it is not edited as extensively to conform with Catholic beliefs. Read about the twelve in Mark, and tell me again how much you trust them to act in Jesus's place. I certainly wouldn't! They were good people, mostly, but they were still human. At its core, the idea that the apostles were some kind of perfect elite and gods on earth is no different from the doctrine of papal infallibility. Each puts its complete faith in a human being!

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.
